org.jtrim.property.swing

Class AutoDisplayState

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jtrim.property.swing.AutoDisplayState

  • public final class AutoDisplayState
extends java.lang.Object
    Defines static utility methods to allow automatically changing the state of Swing components (e.g.: between enabled and disabled).

    The following examples automatically disables a button, if a given JTextField is empty or a JCheckBox is not selected, otherwise the button will be automatically enabled. 

     JTextField textField = ...;
 JCheckBox checkBox = ...;
 JButton button = ...;

 PropertySource condition = and(
         not(equalsWithConst(textProperty(textField), "")),
         buttonSelected(checkBox));
 addSwingStateListener(condition, componentDisabler(button));

    Assuming the following static imports: 

     import static org.jtrim.property.swing.AutoDisplayState.*;
 import static org.jtrim.property.swing.SwingProperties.*;
 import static org.jtrim.property.BoolProperties.*;

    Thread safety

    Methods of this class are safe to be accessed from multiple threads concurrently. Note however that this is not true for the GlassPaneFactory instances.

    Synchronization transparency

    Methods of this class are not synchronization transparent unless otherwise noted. However, they are always safe to be called from the AWT Event Dispatch Thread.

    • Method Detail

      • addSwingStateListener

        public static org.jtrim.event.ListenerRef addSwingStateListener(PropertySource<java.lang.Boolean> property,
                                                BoolPropertyListener stateListener)
        Adds a BoolPropertyListener to be notified on the Event Dispatch Thread whenever the specified property changes. This method does not guarantee that the listener is notified only if the specified property changes. That is, it is possible that the specified listener is notified subsequently with the same argument. However, this should be rare and client code should not need to worry about too much about unnecessary property change notifications.

        This method will cause the BoolPropertyListener to be notified at least once, even if the underlying property does not change. If the calling thread is the Event Dispatch Thread, then it may even be called synchronously by this method.

        See the class documentation for example usages.

        Parameters:
        property - the property whose value is to be checked. This argument cannot be null.
        stateListener - the listener to be notified whenever the value of the specified property changes. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        the ListenerRef which can be used to unregister the currently added listener, so that it will no longer be notified of subsequent changes. This method may never return null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if any of the argument is null

      • addSwingStateListener

        public static org.jtrim.event.ListenerRef addSwingStateListener(PropertySource<java.lang.Boolean> property,
                                                BoolPropertyListener listener1,
                                                BoolPropertyListener listener2,
                                                BoolPropertyListener... others)
        Adds multiple BoolPropertyListener to be notified on the Event Dispatch Thread whenever the specified property changes. This method does not guarantee that the listener is notified only if the specified property changes. That is, it is possible that the specified listener is notified subsequently with the same argument. However, this should be rare and client code should not need to worry about too much about unnecessary property change notifications.

        This method will cause added BoolPropertyListener to be notified at least once, even if the underlying property does not change. If the calling thread is the Event Dispatch Thread, then it may even be called synchronously by this method.

        See the class documentation for example usages.

        Parameters:
        property - the property whose value is to be checked. This argument cannot be null.
        listener1 - the first listener to be notified whenever the value of the specified property changes. This argument cannot be null.
        listener2 - the first listener to be notified whenever the value of the specified property changes. This argument cannot be null.
        others - other listeners to be notified whenever the value of the specified property changes. This argument cannot be null and none of the listeners can be null.
        Returns:
        the ListenerRef which can be used to unregister the currently added listeners, so that they will no longer be notified of subsequent changes. This method may never return null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if any of the argument is null

      • componentDisabler

        public static BoolPropertyListener componentDisabler(java.awt.Component... components)
        Returns a BoolPropertyListener which enables the specified component if it is called with true, disables them if it is called with false.

        Note that this listener must only be notified on the Event Dispatch Thread. The intended use is to use this listener with the addSwingStateListener method.

        Parameters:
        components - the components to be enabled or disabled based on the argument passed to the returned listener. This argument cannot be null and none of its elements can be null.
        Returns:
        a BoolPropertyListener which enables the specified component if it is called with true, disables them if it is called with false. This method may never return null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the component array or any of the specified components is null
        See Also:
        addSwingStateListener(PropertySource, BoolPropertyListener)

      • buttonCaptionSetter

        public static BoolPropertyListener buttonCaptionSetter(javax.swing.AbstractButton button,
                                       java.lang.String textWhenTrue,
                                       java.lang.String textWhenFalse)
        Returns a BoolPropertyListener which sets the text property of the specified Swing button based on the argument passed to the listener.

        Note that this listener must only be notified on the Event Dispatch Thread. The intended use is to use this listener with the addSwingStateListener method.

        Parameters:
        button - the button whose text property is to be set. This argument cannot be null.
        textWhenTrue - the value to be set for the text property of the specified button when the listener is called with true. This argument cannot be null.
        textWhenFalse - the value to be set for the text property of the specified button when the listener is called with false. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        a BoolPropertyListener which sets the text property of the specified Swing button based on the argument passed to the listener. This method may never return null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if any of the arguments is null
        See Also:
        addSwingStateListener(PropertySource, BoolPropertyListener)

      • glassPaneSwitcher

        public static BoolPropertyListener glassPaneSwitcher(javax.swing.RootPaneContainer window,
                                     GlassPaneFactory glassPaneFactory)
        Returns a BoolPropertyListener which sets (replaces) the glass pane of the specified window if the listener is called with false. The glass pane is restored when the listener is called with true. If you want to avoid flickering, if the listener is only notified false for a short period of time before it is notified again with true, then you might want to use the other glassPaneSwitcher method.

        The intended use of this method is that the listener is notified with false when the window is "busy", and true if it is "free".

        Note that this listener must only be notified on the Event Dispatch Thread. The intended use is to use this listener with the addSwingStateListener method.

        Parameters:
        window - the window whose glass pane is to be set. This argument cannot be null and must implement Component.
        glassPaneFactory - the factory creating glass pane for the specified window when the listener is called with false. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        a BoolPropertyListener which sets (replaces) the glass pane of the specified window if the listener is called with false. This method may never returns null.
        See Also:
        addSwingStateListener(PropertySource, BoolPropertyListener), glassPaneSwitcher(RootPaneContainer, DelayedGlassPane)

      • glassPaneSwitcher

        public static BoolPropertyListener glassPaneSwitcher(javax.swing.RootPaneContainer window,
                                     DelayedGlassPane glassPanes)
        Returns a BoolPropertyListener which sets (replaces) the glass pane of the specified window if the listener is called with false. The glass pane is restored when the listener is called with true. If you want to avoid flickering, if the listener is only notified false for a short period of time before it is notified again with true, then you might want to use the other glassPaneSwitcher method.

        This method allows to specify a glass pane which is applied immediately to the component and another which applied after a given timeout if the listener has still not been notified with true. The benefit of this feature is that you can avoid flickering if the false state for the associated property lasts for only a very short period of time. In this case, you may specify an invisible panel for the glass pane to be set immediately and only set the real (visible) glass pane if this timeout elapses. Using the invisible panel, you may block user input for even that short period of time.

        The intended use of this method is that the listener is notified with false when the window is "busy", and true if it is "free".

        Note that this listener must only be notified on the Event Dispatch Thread. The intended use is to use this listener with the addSwingStateListener method.

        Parameters:
        window - the window whose glass pane is to be set. This argument cannot be null and must implement Component.
        glassPanes - the glass panes to replace the glass pane of the given window as specified in the documentation of this method. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        a BoolPropertyListener which sets (replaces) the glass pane of the specified window if the listener is called with false. This method may never returns null.
        See Also:
        addSwingStateListener(PropertySource, BoolPropertyListener), glassPaneSwitcher(RootPaneContainer, GlassPaneFactory)

      • glassPaneSwitcher

        public static BoolPropertyListener glassPaneSwitcher(javax.swing.JLayer<?> component,
                                     GlassPaneFactory glassPaneFactory)
        Returns a BoolPropertyListener which sets (replaces) the glass pane of the specified JLayer if the listener is called with false. The glass pane is restored when the listener is called with true. If you want to avoid flickering, if the listener is only notified false for a short period of time before it is notified again with true, then you might want to use the other glassPaneSwitcher method.

        The intended use of this method is that the listener is notified with false when the component is "busy", and true if it is "free".

        Note that this listener must only be notified on the Event Dispatch Thread. The intended use is to use this listener with the addSwingStateListener method.

        Parameters:
        component - the JLayer whose glass pane is to be set. This argument cannot be null.
        glassPaneFactory - the factory creating glass pane for the specified JLayer when the listener is called with false. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        a BoolPropertyListener which sets (replaces) the glass pane of the specified JLayer if the listener is called with false. This method may never returns null.
        See Also:
        addSwingStateListener(PropertySource, BoolPropertyListener), glassPaneSwitcher(JLayer, DelayedGlassPane)

      • glassPaneSwitcher

        public static BoolPropertyListener glassPaneSwitcher(javax.swing.JLayer<?> component,
                                     DelayedGlassPane glassPanes)
        Returns a BoolPropertyListener which sets (replaces) the glass pane of the specified JLayer if the listener is called with false. The glass pane is restored when the listener is called with true. If you want to avoid flickering, if the listener is only notified false for a short period of time before it is notified again with true, then you might want to use the other glassPaneSwitcher method.

        This method allows to specify a glass pane which is applied immediately to the component and another which applied after a given timeout if the listener has still not been notified with true. The benefit of this feature is that you can avoid flickering if the false state for the associated property lasts for only a very short period of time. In this case, you may specify an invisible panel for the glass pane to be set immediately and only set the real (visible) glass pane if this timeout elapses. Using the invisible panel, you may block user input for even that short period of time.

        The intended use of this method is that the listener is notified with false when the component is "busy", and true if it is "free".

        Note that this listener must only be notified on the Event Dispatch Thread. The intended use is to use this listener with the addSwingStateListener method.

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        a BoolPropertyListener which sets (replaces) the glass pane of the specified JLayer if the listener is called with false. This method may never returns null.
        See Also:
        addSwingStateListener(PropertySource, BoolPropertyListener), glassPaneSwitcher(JLayer, GlassPaneFactory)

      • invisibleGlassPane

        public static GlassPaneFactory invisibleGlassPane()
        Returns a GlassPaneFactory which creates invisible JPanel instances blocking all user inputs if install as a glass pane of a Swing component.

        Note that if the focus is on a particular component, it will still receive user input regardless what is installed for its glass pane. Therefore, if you truly want to block user inputs, you should take away the focus from the component. For example, by requesting the focus for the glass pane.

        Returns:
        a GlassPaneFactory which creates invisible JPanel instances blocking all user inputs if install as a glass pane of a Swing component. This method may never return null.
